title: Task 30

question.text: What is James implying by using even before in his statement?

answers.answer: He expects everyone to be productive before coming to work
answers.feedback: Even before in this context is not an expectation.

answers.answer: Sarah is only productive at work, not before
answers.feedback: James's use of even before suggests that he's surprised Sarah is productive before work, not that she's only productive at work.

answers.answer: Being productive before work is a regular occurrence for everyone
answers.feedback: The use of even before indicates that James finds being productive before work unusually early, not a regular occurrence.

answers.answer: He is surprised that Sarah is productive before arriving at work

dialogue.text: I can't imagine being so productive even before coming to work.

description:
The word even is used to add emphasis to a statement, often highlighting something surprising, unexpected, or extreme.

When combined with before in the phrase even before, it emphasizes that an action or event occurs earlier than usual or expected, adding a sense of surprise or admiration. For example:

Even before the sun rises, she starts her workout. (emphasizes that her workout begins unusually early)

He finished the project even before the deadline. (implies that finishing before the deadline is surprisingly early)

In conversation, using even can express that something is more than what might be considered normal or usual. It makes the statement stronger.
